Q: When is the "Hispanic Heritage Month"?
A: The event will be open on Sept. 15 - Oct. 15, 2024 at Midnight.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Hispanic Heritage Month"?
A: Carnegie Mellon University intentionally fosters a community where all voices and views are heard and respected, which includes religious backgrounds and spiritual beliefs.
Q: Where can I see the "17th International Exhibition of Botanical Art & Illustration"?
A: The event is at Hunt Institute for Botanical Documentation, 5th Fl....
Q: Is there a specific location to enter for the "17th International Exhibition of Botanical Art & Illustration"?
A: Yes, it is held at Hunt Institute for Botanical Documentation, 5th Fl....
Q: When is the "17th International Exhibition of Botanical Art & Illustration"?
A: The event will be open on October 15, 2024 at 9 a.m. - 5 p.m. M-F (to Dec 17).
Q: Can you give me some information about "17th International Exhibition of Botanical Art & Illustration"?
A: This Hunt Institute for Botanical Documentation exhibition includes 43 artworks by 43 artists representing 19 countries.
Q: Where can I see the "30th Annual Andy Awards"?
A: The event is at McConomy Auditorium, Cohon University Center.
Q: Is there a specific location to enter for the "30th Annual Andy Awards"?
A: Yes, it is held at McConomy Auditorium, Cohon University Center.
Q: When is the "30th Annual Andy Awards"?
A: The event will be open on October 15, 2024 at Noon - 2 p.m..
Q: Can you give me some information about "30th Annual Andy Awards"?
A: Join us for this annual celebration as we recognize 59 staff members and 12 teams for their meaningful contributions to Carnegie Mellon University.
Q: Where can I see the "CMU Pantry Hours"?
A: The event is at CMU Pantry.
Q: Is there a specific location to enter for the "CMU Pantry Hours"?
A: Yes, it is held at CMU Pantry.
Q: When is the "CMU Pantry Hours"?
A: The event will be open on October 15, 2024 at 2 - 5 p.m. Weekly (to Dec 20).
Q: Can you give me some information about "CMU Pantry Hours"?
A: The CMU Pantry is a free resource that combats food insecurity by providing food assistance to CMU students and their dependents.
Q: When is the "Invisible Fight: Chronic Illness Support Group"?
A: The event will be open on October 15, 2024 at 4 - 5 p.m. Weekly (to Dec 17).
Q: Can you give me some information about "Invisible Fight: Chronic Illness Support Group"?
A: Living with a chronic illness/medical condition can be an isolating experience. This support group is an opportunity for students who experience chronic conditions (i.e. asthma, diabetes, autoimmune diseases, cancer, and others) to gather in community for support and validation.

Q: Can you give me some information about "LGBTQIA+ Support and Social Group"?
A: Come join us at this safer space for LGBTQIA+ folks to socialize and support one another.

Q: Can you give me some information about "Fall Break; No Classes"?

Q: Where can I see the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: The event is at Hunt Library, Fourth Floor.
Q: Is there a specific location to enter for the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: Yes, it is held at Hunt Library, Fourth Floor.
Q: When is the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: The event will be open on May 23 - June 1, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: This University Libraries’ exhibition celebrates the 40th anniversary of the Architecture Archives, which was founded to create, conserve and promote the rich history of Pittsburgh’s buildings and tell part of the story of this dynamic city.

Q: When is the "Shemini Atzeret"?
A: The event will be open on October 23 - 25, 2024 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Shemini Atzeret"?
A:   Immediately following the seven-day Jewish festival of Sukkot, Shemini Atzeret is observed from sundown to sundown as a festival of the eighth day.    Carnegie Mellon University intentionally fosters a community where all voices and views are heard and respected, which includes religious backgrounds and spiritual beliefs. 
Q: When is the "Simchat Torah"?
A: The event will be open on October 24 - 25, 2024 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Simchat Torah"?
A:   Immediately following Shemini Atzeret, Simchat Torah is a Jewish holiday observed from sundown to sundown to celebrate the completion of the annual reading of the Torah and affirm Torah as a pillar on which to build life.    Carnegie Mellon University intentionally fosters a community where all voices and views are heard and respected, which includes religious backgrounds and spiritual beliefs.

Q: When is the "All Saints’ Day"?
A: The event will be open on November 1, 2024 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "All Saints’ Day"?
A:   This day is honored by many Western Christians, in gratitude for saints who have gone before. The Catholic tradition focuses on canonized saints; Protestant traditions honor a broader definition of sainthood.    Carnegie Mellon University intentionally fosters a community where all voices and views are heard and respected, which includes religious backgrounds and spiritual beliefs. 
Q: When is the "Diwali"?
A: The event will be open on November 1, 2024 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Diwali"?
A:   The festival of lights, which typically lasts five days and symbolizes the spiritual “victory of light over darkness, good over evil and knowledge over ignorance.” The Hindu, Sikh and Jain traditions all honor Diwali, each tradition with its own understanding of the meaning.    Carnegie Mellon University intentionally fosters a community where all voices and views are heard and respected, which includes religious backgrounds and spiritual beliefs. 
Q: When is the "Día de los Muertos"?
A: The event will be open on November 1, 2024 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Día de los Muertos"?
A:   A Mexican holiday associated with All Saints’ Day, celebrated by praying for and remembering departed friends and family members.    Carnegie Mellon University intentionally fosters a community where all voices and views are heard and respected, which includes religious backgrounds and spiritual beliefs.

Q: Is there a specific location to enter for the "Like, Totally Transformative: CMU in the 1980s"?
A: Yes, it is held at Hunt Library Gallery.
Q: When is the "Like, Totally Transformative: CMU in the 1980s"?
A: The event will be open on Aug. 30 - Nov. 27, 2024 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Like, Totally Transformative: CMU in the 1980s"?
A: This University Libraries’ exhibit is a portal to the past, a snapshot of life on campus more than four decades ago as our world began to transform!
Q: When is the "Native American Heritage Month"?
A: The event will be open on November 1 - 30, 2024 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Native American Heritage Month"?
A: Carnegie Mellon University intentionally fosters a community where all voices and views are heard and respected, which includes religious backgrounds and spiritual beliefs.

A: This workshop will identify how to best collect, ethically use and manage community-based data projects for citizen science use.

Q: Where can I see the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?

Q: Is there a specific location to enter for the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?

Q: When is the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: The event will be open on May 23 - June 1, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: This University Libraries’ exhibition celebrates the 40th anniversary of the Architecture Archives, which was founded to create, conserve and promote the rich history of Pittsburgh’s buildings and tell part of the story of this dynamic city.

A:   The Academic Calendar includes registration dates, class start dates, add/drop deadlines, exam dates, and more. Doctoral course-sections follow a separate academic calendar.    Calendars for Heinz College, Tepper School of Business graduate courses, CMU-Africa, CMU-Australia, and CMU-Qatar can be found on The HUB Academic Calendar web page.

Q: When is the "Invisible Fight: Chronic Illness Support Group"?
A: The event will be open on November 19, 2024 at 4 - 5 p.m. Weekly (to Dec 17).
Q: Can you give me some information about "Invisible Fight: Chronic Illness Support Group"?
A: Living with a chronic illness/medical condition can be an isolating experience. This support group is an opportunity for students who experience chronic conditions (i.e. asthma, diabetes, autoimmune diseases, cancer, and others) to gather in community for support and validation.

Q: Can you give me some information about "CMU Pantry Hours"?
A: The CMU Pantry is a free resource that combats food insecurity by providing food assistance to CMU students and their dependents.
Q: When is the "PhD Student Support Group"?
A: The event will be open on November 25, 2024 at 6:30 - 7:30 p.m. Weekly (to Dec 13).
Q: Can you give me some information about "PhD Student Support Group"?
A: The PhD Support Group offers space to confidentially discuss the stressors and challenges of navigating relationships with advisors and peers, academic milestones, academic hazing, low motivation, struggles with self-confidence, and efforts to lead a more balanced life.
Q: Where can I see the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: The event is at Hunt Library, Fourth Floor.
Q: Is there a specific location to enter for the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: Yes, it is held at Hunt Library, Fourth Floor.
Q: When is the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: The event will be open on May 23 - June 1, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: This University Libraries’ exhibition celebrates the 40th anniversary of the Architecture Archives, which was founded to create, conserve and promote the rich history of Pittsburgh’s buildings and tell part of the story of this dynamic city.
Q: Where can I see the "Like, Totally Transformative: CMU in the 1980s"?
A: The event is at Hunt Library Gallery.
Q: Is there a specific location to enter for the "Like, Totally Transformative: CMU in the 1980s"?
A: Yes, it is held at Hunt Library Gallery.
Q: When is the "Like, Totally Transformative: CMU in the 1980s"?
A: The event will be open on Aug. 30 - Nov. 27, 2024 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Like, Totally Transformative: CMU in the 1980s"?
A: This University Libraries’ exhibit is a portal to the past, a snapshot of life on campus more than four decades ago as our world began to transform!
Q: When is the "Mini-2 pass/no pass & withdrawal deadline"?
A: The event will be open on November 25, 2024 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Mini-2 pass/no pass & withdrawal deadline"?
A:   The Academic Calendar includes registration dates, class start dates, add/drop deadlines, exam dates, and more. Doctoral course-sections follow a separate academic calendar.    Calendars for Heinz College, Tepper School of Business graduate courses, CMU-Africa, CMU-Australia, and CMU-Qatar can be found on The HUB Academic Calendar web page.

A: This Hunt Institute for Botanical Documentation exhibition includes 43 artworks by 43 artists representing 19 countries.

A: Yes, it is held at CMU Pantry.

A: The event will be open on November 26, 2024 at 2 - 5 p.m. Weekly (to Dec 20).

Q: When is the "Invisible Fight: Chronic Illness Support Group"?
A: The event will be open on November 26, 2024 at 4 - 5 p.m. Weekly (to Dec 17).
Q: Can you give me some information about "Invisible Fight: Chronic Illness Support Group"?
A: Living with a chronic illness/medical condition can be an isolating experience. This support group is an opportunity for students who experience chronic conditions (i.e. asthma, diabetes, autoimmune diseases, cancer, and others) to gather in community for support and validation.

Q: When is the "Day of the Covenant (Baha’i)"?
A: The event will be open on November 26, 2024 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Day of the Covenant (Baha’i)"?
A:   Baha’is remember the appointment of Abdu’l-Baha as the center of Baha’u’llah’s covenant and celebrate the unity of their faith, and the basic unity of all faiths.    Carnegie Mellon University intentionally fosters a community where all voices and views are heard and respected, which includes religious backgrounds and spiritual beliefs.

Q: Can you give me some information about "Human Rights Day"?
A:   This day commemorates the signing of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights by the United Nations General Assembly in Paris on Dec. 10, 1948. This declaration recognizes that all human beings in all nations have inherent rights and dignity.    Carnegie Mellon University intentionally fosters a community where all voices and views are heard and respected, which includes religious backgrounds and spiritual beliefs.

Q: When is the "Yalda Night"?
A: The event will be open on December 20, 2024 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Yalda Night"?
A:   Also known as Chelleh Night, this Iranian festival marks the winter solstice, the longest night of the year. Participants celebrate by uniting with friends and family to eat, drink, and read poetry.    Carnegie Mellon University intentionally fosters a community where all voices and views are heard and respected, which includes religious backgrounds and spiritual beliefs.

A:   Holiday when many Christians commemorate the birth of Jesus Christ.    Carnegie Mellon University intentionally fosters a community where all voices and views are heard and respected, which includes religious backgrounds and spiritual beliefs. 
Q: When is the "Hanukkah"?
A: The event will be open on Dec. 25 - Jan. 2, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Hanukkah"?
A:   Also known as the Festival of Lights, Hanukkah is an eight-day Jewish holiday celebrating the re-dedication of the Second Temple in Jerusalem in the second century A.D. It is often celebrated with the lighting of menorah candles, as well as traditional foods, games, and gifts.    Carnegie Mellon University intentionally fosters a community where all voices and views are heard and respected, which includes religious backgrounds and spiritual beliefs.

A: Yes, it is held at Hunt Library, Fourth Floor.

A: The event will be open on May 23 - June 1, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: This University Libraries’ exhibition celebrates the 40th anniversary of the Architecture Archives, which was founded to create, conserve and promote the rich history of Pittsburgh’s buildings and tell part of the story of this dynamic city.

Q: Can you give me some information about "Feast of the Epiphany / Día de los Reyes / Theophany of our Lord"?
A: Though it is called by many names, on January 6, Christians of different traditions celebrate the visit of the three magi to worship Jesus Christ. The details of how this holy day is honored vary among Christian traditions and cultures, including Eastern Orthodoxy.

A: The event will be open on February 1, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Imbolc or St. Brigid’s Day"?
A: Imbolc is a pagan sabbat that honors a spirit of renewal and new beginnings. This day is also celebrated by some Christians in or from the British Isles, who know the day as St. Brigid’s Day. There are various ways of observing the day, depending on one’s religious tradition.

Q: When is the "Ramadan"?
A: The event will be open on Feb. 28 - March 29, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Ramadan"?
A: Ramadan is one of the most important Muslim seasons, commemorating the revelation of the Qur’an to the Prophet Mohamed. Many Muslims fast from both food and drink between sunrise and sunset, honor halal food guidelines when they break the fast with the iftar meal, and spend more time reading the Qu’ran and praying, either alone or at a mosque.

Q: When is the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: The event will be open on May 23 - June 1, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: This University Libraries’ exhibition celebrates the 40th anniversary of the Architecture Archives, which was founded to create, conserve and promote the rich history of Pittsburgh’s buildings and tell part of the story of this dynamic city.

Q: Can you give me some information about "Ramadan"?
A: Ramadan is one of the most important Muslim seasons, commemorating the revelation of the Qur’an to the Prophet Mohamed. Many Muslims fast from both food and drink between sunrise and sunset, honor halal food guidelines when they break the fast with the iftar meal, and spend more time reading the Qu’ran and praying, either alone or at a mosque.

Q: When is the "Great Lent"?
A: The event will be open on March 3 - 5, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Great Lent"?
A: Eastern Orthodox Christians begin observing 7 weeks of Great Lent on March 3, with Clean Monday. Great Lent is observed with fasting and prayer in the season of preparation for the Holy Feast of Pascha, celebrating Jesus’ resurrection on April 20.

Q: When is the "Ash Wednesday"?
A: The event will be open on March 5, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Ash Wednesday"?
A: Some Western Christians honor Ash Wednesday as the first day of Lent, which is the period of 40 days before Easter in which they may sacrifice ordinary pleasures to reflect on Christ’s sacrifice. On this day, there are special church services and participants may receive a cross of ashes marked on their foreheads. Christians may abstain from meat on this day.

Q: Can you give me some information about "International Women’s Day"?
A: Growing from European and North American suffrage and labor movements in the twentieth century, International Women’s Day highlights both present and past leadership of women and ongoing advocacy for women’s rights throughout the world.

A: Ramadan is one of the most important Muslim seasons, commemorating the revelation of the Qur’an to the Prophet Mohamed. Many Muslims fast from both food and drink between sunrise and sunset, honor halal food guidelines when they break the fast with the iftar meal, and spend more time reading the Qu’ran and praying, either alone or at a mosque.
Q: When is the "Women’s History Month"?
A: The event will be open on March 1 - 31, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Women’s History Month"?
A: Since 1980, Women’s History Month has celebrated the achievements and leadership of women in the United States.
Q: Where can I see the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: The event is at Hunt Library, Fourth Floor.
Q: Is there a specific location to enter for the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: Yes, it is held at Hunt Library, Fourth Floor.
Q: When is the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: The event will be open on May 23 - June 1, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: This University Libraries’ exhibition celebrates the 40th anniversary of the Architecture Archives, which was founded to create, conserve and promote the rich history of Pittsburgh’s buildings and tell part of the story of this dynamic city.
Q: When is the "Lent / Great Lent"?
A: The event will be open on March 6 - April 12, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Lent / Great Lent"?
A: This year, the season of Lent, which is honored by some Western Christians, and Great Lent of Eastern Orthodoxy, are overlapping. Observations include forms of fasting and prayer.
Q: When is the "Purim"?
A: The event will be open on March 13 - 14, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Purim"?
A: On March 13-14, Jews celebrate Purim with a feast and gifts of charity for people in need. They remember the story of Queen Esther and the survival of the Jewish people in the face of annihilation.

Q: When is the "Holi"?
A: The event will be open on March 14, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Holi"?
A: On March 14, Hindus celebrate Holi, which is known as the Festival of Colors, Festival of Spring, and the Festival of Love. It marks the arrival of spring, the divine love of Radha Krishna, and the victory of good over evil with a celebration of color and maybe attendance at their temple. This year, CMU will hold its own celebration of Holi on April 6, the Sunday of Carnival weekend.

Q: When is the "Mini-4 add, audit & tuition adjustment drop deadline"?
A: The event will be open on March 14, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Mini-4 add, audit & tuition adjustment drop deadline"?
A:   The Academic Calendar includes registration dates, class start dates, add/drop deadlines, exam dates, and more. Doctoral course-sections follow a separate academic calendar.    Calendars for Heinz College, Tepper School of Business graduate courses, CMU-Africa, CMU-Australia, and CMU-Qatar can be found on The HUB Academic Calendar web page.

Q: When is the "Naw Rúz"?
A: The event will be open on March 19 - 20, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Naw Rúz"?
A: Rooted in Zoroastrianism, March 20 or 21 is the New Year celebration for Bahá’ís and Iranians. For some, it marks the end of 19 days of fasting. Naw Rúz celebrations include a feast with traditional and symbolic foods and giving gifts.

Q: When is the "Ostara"?
A: The event will be open on March 20, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Ostara"?
A: On March 20, Wiccans and Neo-pagans celebrate Ostara, which occurs on the Spring Equinox. It is named after the Anglo-Saxon goddess, Eostre. Ostara rituals and gatherings focus on fertility, rebirth, and renewal.

A: Ramadan is one of the most important Muslim seasons, commemorating the revelation of the Qur’an to the Prophet Mohamed. Many Muslims fast from both food and drink between sunrise and sunset, honor halal food guidelines when they break the fast with the iftar meal, and spend more time reading the Qu’ran and praying, either alone or at a mosque.
Q: When is the "Women’s History Month"?
A: The event will be open on March 1 - 31, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Women’s History Month"?
A: Since 1980, Women’s History Month has celebrated the achievements and leadership of women in the United States.
Q: Where can I see the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: The event is at Hunt Library, Fourth Floor.
Q: Is there a specific location to enter for the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: Yes, it is held at Hunt Library, Fourth Floor.
Q: When is the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: The event will be open on May 23 - June 1, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: This University Libraries’ exhibition celebrates the 40th anniversary of the Architecture Archives, which was founded to create, conserve and promote the rich history of Pittsburgh’s buildings and tell part of the story of this dynamic city.

A: The event will be open on March 6 - April 12, 2025 all day.

A: This year, the season of Lent, which is honored by some Western Christians, and Great Lent of Eastern Orthodoxy, are overlapping. Observations include forms of fasting and prayer.

Q: When is the "Eid al-Fitr"?
A: The event will be open on March 30 - 31, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Eid al-Fitr"?
A: On Eid al-Fitr, Muslims gather to celebrate the festival of breaking the Ramadan fast by praying to Allah, sharing presents, and feasting with friends and relatives. The celebration begins at sundown, the evening before the appointed day. The March 30 or 31 date is approximate, with the final date determined by the sight of the moon.

Q: When is the "Ram Navami"?
A: The event will be open on April 6, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Ram Navami"?
A: Ram Navami, which occurs on April 5, celebrates the birth of Lord Rama. To honor this day, Hindus clean and decorate their houses with fruits and flowers. They put an image of Rama as a baby in a cradle, and at midday, they remove the cover of the cradle and feed a special food (called Prasad) to him.

Calendars for Heinz College, Tepper School of Business graduate courses, CMU-Africa, CMU-Australia, and CMU-Qatar can be found on The HUB Academic Calendar web page. 
Q: Where can I see the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: The event is at Hunt Library, Fourth Floor.
Q: Is there a specific location to enter for the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: Yes, it is held at Hunt Library, Fourth Floor.
Q: When is the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: The event will be open on May 23 - June 1, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: This University Libraries’ exhibition celebrates the 40th anniversary of the Architecture Archives, which was founded to create, conserve and promote the rich history of Pittsburgh’s buildings and tell part of the story of this dynamic city.
Q: When is the "Lent / Great Lent"?
A: The event will be open on March 6 - April 12, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Lent / Great Lent"?
A: This year, the season of Lent, which is honored by some Western Christians, and Great Lent of Eastern Orthodoxy, are overlapping. Observations include forms of fasting and prayer.
Q: When is the "National Arab American Heritage Month"?
A: The event will be open on April 1 - 30, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "National Arab American Heritage Month"?
A: National Arab American Heritage Month - During Arab American Heritage Month, the US celebrates the cultural and leadership contributions of Arab Americans.

A: The event will be open on April 7 - 12, 2025 all day.

Q: When is the "Mahavir Jayanti"?
A: The event will be open on April 10, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Mahavir Jayanti"?
A: On April 10, the Jain Community celebrates Mahavir Jayanti, the birthday of Lord Mahavir, who taught non-violence, peace, and harmony. The day is honored with special decorations depicting Lord Mahavir, charitable acts, and prayers in Jain temples.
Q: When is the "National Arab American Heritage Month"?

Q: When is the "Day of Silence"?
A: The event will be open on April 11, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Day of Silence"?
A: The Day of Silence is a student-led national event to highlight the silencing and erasure of LGBTQ+ people. Participants take a vow of silence for the day, which ends with a Breaking the Silence rally to speak about their experiences and raise awareness of ways that schools and communities can be more inclusive.

Q: When is the "Passover"?
A: The event will be open on April 12 - 20, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Passover"?
A: Passover (or Pesach, in Hebrew) is celebrated in remembrance of the Israelites being freed from slavery in ancient Egypt and lasts from April 12-20 this year. Beginning at sundown the night before, rituals include telling the story, fasting from leavened bread, and participating in family seder meals. Many Jews keep kosher food restrictions during this festival and attend additional religious services.

Q: When is the "Holy Week or Passion Week"?
A: The event will be open on April 13 - 19, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Holy Week or Passion Week"?
A: Beginning with Palm Sunday on April 13, Eastern Orthodox Christians and some Western Christians commemorate the last week before Pascha or Easter Day with Passion Week or Holy Week. There are special worship services and observances such as prayer, fasting, and confession on multiple days, depending on the specific denomination.

Many Jews keep kosher food restrictions during this festival and attend additional religious services.
Q: When is the "Theravada New Year"?
A: The event will be open on April 13, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Theravada New Year"?
A: This year on April 13, Theravada Buddhists celebrate the new year with traditions that focus on water, understanding that it cleanses the negativity of the previous year. It’s also a time for giving to charity as a way of growing in enlightenment.

Q: When is the "Vaisakhi"?
A: The event will be open on April 14, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Vaisakhi"?
A: Vaisakhi – which is also called Lohri, Pongal, Sankranthi, Gudi Padwa, and Varsh Pratipada – marks the birth of the Sikh faith, which occurred during the traditional harvest festival in Punjab. Sikh and Hindu celebrations of this festival day (April 14) may include visits to Gurdwaras, special decorations, and singing hymns.

Q: Can you give me some information about "Easter Sunday or Holy Pascha"?
A: This year both Western Christian and Eastern Orthodox Churches will be celebrating Easter Sunday and Holy Pascha on the same day, in celebration of Jesus’ resurrection from the dead. Many Christians celebrate Easter with special church services, music, and meals.

Q: When is the "Ridván"?
A: The event will be open on April 20 - May 2, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Ridván"?
A: Ridván is a 12-day festival which translates from Arabic to mean “paradise.” Though it lasts from April 20 - May 2, Baha’is observe the three holy days of the festival— the first, ninth, and twelfth—with community gatherings and rest from work.
Q: Where can I see the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: The event is at Hunt Library, Fourth Floor.
Q: Is there a specific location to enter for the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: Yes, it is held at Hunt Library, Fourth Floor.
Q: When is the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: The event will be open on May 23 - June 1, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: This University Libraries’ exhibition celebrates the 40th anniversary of the Architecture Archives, which was founded to create, conserve and promote the rich history of Pittsburgh’s buildings and tell part of the story of this dynamic city.
Q: When is the "National Arab American Heritage Month"?
A: The event will be open on April 1 - 30, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "National Arab American Heritage Month"?
A: National Arab American Heritage Month - During Arab American Heritage Month, the US celebrates the cultural and leadership contributions of Arab Americans.

A: The event will be open on April 20 - May 2, 2025 all day.

Q: When is the "Earth Day"?
A: The event will be open on April 22, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Earth Day"?
A: The United States celebrates Earth Day on April 22, with participants engaging in acts of care, support, or advocacy that respond proactively to climate change, preserve our ecosystems, and/or protect biodiversity.

Q: When is the "Yom HaShoah"?
A: The event will be open on April 23, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Yom HaShoah"?
A: This year, April 23 marks Yom HaShoah as the Jewish “Day of (remembrance of) the Holocaust and the Heroism,” which is honored in Israel and around the world. Some Jewish synagogues hold commemorative services or community programs that feature presentations from or about survivors.

Q: When is the "Beltane"?
A: The event will be open on May 1, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Beltane"?
A: Beltane, which means “bright fire” in Gaelic, is celebrated on May 1 and represents the beginning of summer in early Celtic traditions. Current Wiccan and Pagan practices honor Beltane by holding ceremonies that honor fertility, creativity, and rebirth, and fires are lit.

Q: Is there a specific location to enter for the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: Yes, it is held at Hunt Library, Fourth Floor.
Q: When is the "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: The event will be open on May 23 - June 1, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives"?
A: This University Libraries’ exhibition celebrates the 40th anniversary of the Architecture Archives, which was founded to create, conserve and promote the rich history of Pittsburgh’s buildings and tell part of the story of this dynamic city.
Q: When is the "Jewish American Heritage"?
A: The event will be open on May 1 - 31, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Jewish American Heritage"?
A: Jewish American Heritage month recognizes how Jewish values, culture, and contributions have positively impacted the United States.
Q: When is the "Semester & Mini-4 Faculty Course Evaluations close"?
A: The event will be open on May 5, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Semester & Mini-4 Faculty Course Evaluations close"?
A:   The Academic Calendar includes registration dates, class start dates, add/drop deadlines, exam dates, and more. Doctoral course-sections follow a separate academic calendar.    Calendars for Heinz College, Tepper School of Business graduate courses, CMU-Africa, CMU-Australia, and CMU-Qatar can be found on The HUB Academic Calendar web page. 
Q: When is the "Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month"?
A: The event will be open on May 1 - 31, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month"?
A: This month recognizes the contributions and influence of Asian Americans, Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islander Americans to the culture and achievements of the United States.

Q: When is the "Declaration of the Bab"?
A: The event will be open on May 23, 2025 all day.
Q: Can you give me some information about "Declaration of the Bab"?
A: On May 23, Baha’is celebrate the day that Bahá’u’lláh, the founder of the Bahá’í Faith, received a revelation. Many followers do not work on this day.
